metadata.title: Build and Deploy a Deep Learning Image Classification App | by Jeff Hale | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Build and Deploy a Deep Learning Image Classification App
metadata.description: In this article I’ll show you how to go from concept to deployment with a computer vision classification model. With fastai you can quickly build and train a state-of-the-art deep learning model…

all_paragraphs: In this article I’ll show you how to go from concept to deployment with a computer vision classification model. With fastai you can quickly build and train a state-of-the-art deep learning model. Then, Render makes hosting and deploying your app a breeze.
We’ll go step-by-step as we build and deploy a model to classify skin lesion images. When finished, users will be able upload an image to a website and the model will classify their skin lesion.
I plan to write a similar article on NLP soon — follow me to make sure you don’t miss it! 😄
Health/legal: This project is for demonstration purposes only. If you think you may have a skin problem, go see a health care professional. I’m not a health care professional.

Technical: This example isn’t intended for a large-scale website with millions of hits. If you have that issue — well, that’s a good problem to have. 😀 This setup might work. Render uses Docker and Kubernetes behind the scenes to make scaling as close to painless as possible.
Alright — back to the action!

Skin cancers are the most common group of cancers. A number of apps have been developed to classify skin lesions. By uploading a picture of your suspicious skin spot you can see if you should talk to a dermatologist.
Let’s flesh this plan out a bit. 😉
It looks like there’s an annual ISIC competition on a several aspects of the data— info here. You can see images with different filters here.

I found the same dataset is on Kaggle to classify skin lesions. Kaggle’s space limit and shared Docker container memory limit might keep us from being able to do what we want, so we might need to move to Colab. See my article for a discussion of choosing between Kaggle and Colab.

The skin lesion images are zipped in two zipped folders. I did’t see an easy way to combine the files from two zipped dataset folders on Kaggle. I downloaded the data, zipped it and re-upload it. Now you can use the data in one folder on Kaggle here. 😄
There’s one file with metadata: HAM10000_metadata.csv. That’s handy. Here are the contents and my initial thoughts:

lesion_id — one for each lesion. Each lesion can have more than one image.image_id — lists the image id for each lesion. These are also the file names, sans .jpg.dx — diagnosis. 7 types. Should be the DV, I expect.dx_type — how the diagnosis was made.age — 57 values missing. Could try different strategies for dealing with.sex — 3 values.localization —location on the body. 15 values.
There are more images than unique cases. Hmm. I dug up here that this is because the same image is included at different magnifications. This is a little de facto data augmentation.

How many classification labels exist for the outcome variable? Seven: melanocytic nevi, melanoma, benign keratosis, basal cell carcinoma, actinic keratoses, vascular lesions, dermatofibroma. Note that melanoma is the most dangerous type of skin cancer. You also don’t want basal cell carcinoma —the most frequent type of skin cancer. Actinic keratoses is considered a potential precancer.
It doesn’t look like any images are classified as more than one type, so we have a multi-class problem, but not a multi-label problem.
Is the data unbalanced? Yes, 67% are class nv, which stands for melanocytic nevi.

We need to be careful with our reporting metrics with unbalanced classes. Accuracy, for example, won’t be a very insightful metric. However, according to fast.ai’s Jeremy Howard, we don’t need to worry about the unbalanced dataset when training with deep learning models. The network will figure out the classes.
We’ll import our usual libraries and configure things for deep learning. Because Kaggle doesn’t have the latest PyTorch and fastai libraries, we’ll turn on the internet and install those with pip.
Let’s also turn on our GPU. We’ll then list our hardware and software for reproducibility — and to make sure we have the resources we think we do

I switched to Colab while I grew tired of waiting for my combined data file to upload. I realized that I could use the Kaggle API to get the dataset from Kaggle and into Colab. Then I merged the image files and saved them in a Google Drive folder. This was kind of a hassle, but now that the data is in my Drive folder, it’s pretty convenient. 😄 Here’s my Colab notebook.

Let’s use a subset of the data first for fast training to get everything working. No reason to spend lots of time waiting for training when we just want to see if we’re on the right path. We’ll start with a random sample of 1,000 images for our training and validation set, instead of 10,015. We can use the full dataset later, once we have the kinks ironed out.
Train-test split — fastai will split our data into training and validation sets. We’ll set aside 20% of the images for validation.

Transfer learning — let’s use ResNet34 at first; it’s good enough and fast enough to get started. Later, we’ll move to ResNet50 later if we want to spend more time training for potentially higher accuracy.
Optimizer — I’m using the default: Adam.

Layers — The default fastai layers for a CNN are explained here. These are blocks of PyTorch layers with batchnorm, dropout, linear, and Relu functions. The final set of layers consists of a 2d pooling layer and a flattening layer.

Learning Rate —We’ll use learning rate annealing following Leslie Smith’s 1Cycle Policy. We’ll start with fastai’s default learning rate of 3E-10 for the first epochs (which was verified as suitable with the fastai learning rate finder). After unfreezing, we’ll create a range of learning rates for the 1Cycle Policy with the learning rate finder and the rule of thumb to decrease the previous learning rate by 10x.
Loss Function — We have a multi-classification project, so we’ll use categorical cross-entropy.
Evaluation — Let’s track the error rate, precision, and sensitivity. We’ll also dig into the confusion matrix.

I trained the smaller subset of data and got everything working. Then I switched to the full dataset. After training for four epochs, unfreezing, and training for four more epochs, we have a baseline model with a 15% error rate. That’s good enough for our purposes. Let’s try to deploy our model.
Here are the five steps to get a model deployed.
Your app should automatically deploy on push. You can see events and logs for your app in your Render dashboard.

It takes a few minutes for the app to deploy. You can watch the progress in the dashboard. In my brief experience, Render had good customer support — they quickly answered my question via their Slack channel.
You can check out my live app here: https://skin-render.onrender.com/. I’ll probably take it down in a few weeks, so if this link doesn’t work for you, that’s why. 😄
You can also run your app locally. In fact, if you’re using Jupyter Lab, you can see your app in your notebook, which is super cool!
Here are the three steps to see your app in your notebook:
Your app should be running in your cell’s output.
Awesome! Render is pretty slick. Now let’s see if we can improve our model.
Let’s train the model for longer now and try to improve the accuracy with hyper-parameter tuning. We’ll use mixed-precision training to try to speed the training, as I describe in this article.

Using half-precision training and a batch size of 64 with 8 total epochs resulted in an error rate of 14%. That doesn’t sound too bad. But then I looked at the confusion matrix and saw that nearly half the total melanoma cases were classified with benign labels. That’s a problem. 😟
I worked on a number of potential fixes. The best model used transfer learning with ResNet50, 12 total training epochs, a batch size of 64, and floating point precision of 32.
The error rate is now down to 10.7% and here’s the confusion matrix:

I don’t know that I’d use this model in the wild; there are still too many melanoma misclassifications. Nonetheless, let’s call this project “done for now” and discuss potential future directions you could pursue.

These images were in good shape, and getting them into the right format wasn’t too tough. Getting Kaggle and Colab to work with the data sources took the most work. Kaggle and Colab both have their hurdles, but they are free. 😄

Waiting for Colab’s K80 GPU to train your model gets old. It’s fine for ironing out a small model in the early stages, but if you want to test a bunch of hyperparameters, it’s probably worth moving to a paid service. I found Google Cloud Platform (GCP) the easiest cloud provider to use with good value. See my article comparing cloud GPU providers here. I would probably use a V100 on GCP if I were going to train these models further.
The size of the training dataset was important. The model didn’t train as well when it was training with 800 observations instead of 8k.
Fastai and Render make a great team. Fastai is good for creating strong-performing models quickly and Render makes deploying them a snap. 👍

In this article you saw how you can from idea to live web app for a fine-grained multi-class computer vision problem. I hope you found this article useful. If you have, please share it on your favorite social media channel so others can find it, too. 👏
I hope this project has inspired you to build that deep learning app you’ve been thinking about. 😄
I write about Python, dev ops, data science, and other tech topics. If any of those are of interest to you follow me and check them out here.
Here are the images and metadata on Kaggle, originally uploaded by Kevin Mader. Now the images are available in one folder that I uploaded to Kaggle here. My Colab notebook is here.
Here are Kaggle Kernels that have used the same original dataset. And here are two other Medium articles that discuss tackling this problem: 1, 2.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
